THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of
  Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Reginald Tyrell Clea, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Sumter County
Clifton Newman, Circuit
  Court Judge
Unpublished
  Opinion No. 2007-UP-552
Submitted
  December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed December 14, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, South Carolina Commission of Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General
  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka,
  Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Â Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor C.
  Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â 
  Reginald Tyrell Clea (Clea) was convicted of one count of murder and possession
  of a firearm during the commission of a crime of violence.Â  He was acquitted on
  a second murder charge.Â  On appeal, Clea argues the trial judge erred in not
  charging the jury on the lesser included offense of voluntary manslaughter. Â Â We
  affirm.[1]
FACTS
Clea
  admittedly shot and killed Charles Jackson (Jackson) and James Pollard
  (Pollard).Â  John Lee Powell (Lee) testified he was with Pollard the day of the
  shootings.Â  Pollard picked Lee up earlier in the day, and they were later
  joined by Maurice Young (Young).Â  They drove together to Rembert to find Clea
  and buy doghouses from him.Â  Pollard and Clea had shared a residence prior to
  the shootings and had bred dogs.Â  Clea left several dogs at Pollardâ€™s new home,
  and the dogs did not have doghouses.Â  Â Â Pollard paid Clea for the doghouses,
  and all four men amicably loaded them onto Cleaâ€™s truck.Â   
The
  group drove to Pollardâ€™s new home and, as they were unloading, Jackson arrived in his car.Â  Jackson spoke cordially with Lee and then approached Pollard.Â 
  The group continued to interact in a friendly manner when Jackson called Clea
  over to Jacksonâ€™s car so he could â€œshowâ€ him â€œsomething.â€Â  Lee said Jacksonâ€™s tone was good natured.Â  When Lee heard the first shots, his back was to Clea, but
  he turned to see Clea shooting at Jackson.Â  He asked Clea why he was shooting at
  Jackson, and Clea repeatedly answered that Jackson had a gun.Â  Clea fired
  again as Jackson crawled through his car to exit the passenger side.Â  Lee told
  Clea to stop shooting, but Clea again replied Jackson had a gun.Â  Lee never saw
  Jackson with a gun, nor did he hear shots come from Jacksonâ€™s direction.
 
Pollard,
  who was near the car, asked Clea why he was shooting at Jackson and Clea turned
  towards him.Â  As Pollard walked towards Clea repeating his question, Clea
  started shooting at Pollard.Â  Lee did not see a weapon on Pollard and had no indication
  he was armed.Â  He heard Clea ask Jackson to show his hand, but Lee was unable
  to observe Jackson who now lay on the ground on the opposite side of the car.Â  Jackson yelled numerous times for Pollard to tell Clea he didnâ€™t have a gun, however
  Pollard had already been shot.Â  After Lee and Young left the yard, Lee heard
  another set of gunfire.
Young
  testified to being at Pollardâ€™s home unloading the doghouses.Â  Soon after Jackson arrived, he heard gunshots and turned to see Clea shoot at Jackson.Â  He didnâ€™t see
  Jackson shoot back and saw no gun other than Cleaâ€™s.Â  After the first shots,
  he recalled Clea said Jackson was going to get a gun. Â Jackson stated, â€œno, I
  ainâ€™t got no gun, I ainâ€™t got no gun.â€Â  Young heard Lee tell Clea to put the
  gun down, and he heard more shots as he left the yard.
According
  to Cleaâ€™s testimony, he sold the doghouses to Pollard as a last detail from
  their having lived together.Â  He explained he had previous difficulties with the
  victims and knew both had reputations for violence.Â  The day of the shooting, Pollard
  and Young stopped him on the road to discuss the doghouses.Â  No one was upset
  and no â€œcross wordsâ€ were exchanged.Â  Clea helped load the doghouses onto his
  truck, drove them to Pollardâ€™s residence, and unloaded one with Pollardâ€™s
  help.Â  Jackson drove up shortly afterwards, and they worked together to unload
  another doghouse.Â   
When
  Jackson told Clea he needed to talk with him, Clea reported he was not
  suspicious at first. Â But, as he walked toward the car and his truck, â€œa chill
  went up [his] back.â€Â  Because he did not want to speak with Jackson, he
  continued towards his truck â€œso [he] could leave.â€Â  As Clea was about to sit in
  the truck, he saw Jackson reach into the carâ€™s backseat and pick up a shoebox.Â 
  Jackson continued to call Clea to the car.Â  While Clea â€œwas stalling . . .Â 
  putting Vaseline on my lips because it was cold,â€ Jackson began â€œtalking
  aggressively.â€Â  Clea thought Jackson was going to get a gun from the box.Â  He
  told Jackson, â€œif you want me to come over there, why you donâ€™t come to me.Â 
  And thatâ€™s when [Jackson] be like, nah, I want you to come to me.Â  And thatâ€™s
  when I slammed my backseat back, threw on my jacketâ€ and reached for the loaded
  assault rifle.Â   
Clea
  said he couldnâ€™t leave because no safe exit from the yard was available.Â  â€œ[A]t
  first,â€ he didnâ€™t think Jackson had a gun; but, when he saw that Jackson â€œwas clamping on to something,â€ he thought â€œlike, man, forget thatâ€ and shot at
  the front of the car in which Jackson sat.Â  He called these first shots
  â€œwarning signs,â€ and he told Jackson â€œto let [him] leave from the scene because
  [he] was about to leave anyway.â€Â  When Clea demanded â€œlet me see your hand,â€ Jackson did not comply.Â  The solicitor asked Clea:
 

	
		
			Q: 
			Was there anything that he did 
			that provoked you into a fight with him?  Is there anything he 
			did to make you mad?  Did he call you a name or do anything 
			like that that got you heated up?  
 
		
		
			A:  
			What got me heated up was he 
			wouldnâ€™t show me his hands. 
 
		
		
			Q:
			All right, what Iâ€™m trying to 
			ask you is if there was any hostility, if there was anything that 
			got you mad at him, angry at him, outraged at him?
 
		
		
			A: 
			I never said I was mad. 
			
 
		
		
			Q:
			Whatâ€™s that?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Whoever said I was mad?
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Iâ€™m asking you that.  Are 
			you telling me you werenâ€™t mad? 
 
		
		
			A: 
			No, I was just precautious.
 
		
		
			. . . 
 
			 
		
		
			Q: 
			Did Mr. Pollard ever say 
			anything or do anything to you that made you mad or angry?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yeah, when he kept hollering to 
			me and looking for me, wanting me to give an explanation about 
			something that I didnâ€™t had no â€“ that I didnâ€™t had no right to give 
			him an explanation about.
 
		
		
			. . .
 
			 
		
		
			Q:   
			
			Iâ€™m asking you if Mr. Jackson â€“ 
			if Mr. Pollard on this day ever said anything to you or did anything 
			to you that got you mad, that got you outraged?
 
		
		
			A: 
			
			No, sir.
 
		
		
			Q:  
			Did he ever provoke you by 
			calling you a name or by doing anything else, provoke you into the 
			point where you just said you had to shoot him for no other reason?
 
		
		
			A:  
			Yes.
 
		
		
			Q:
			How did he provoke you? 
			
 
		
		
			A:
			By reaching into his waist.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			That made you mad?
 
		
		
			A: 
			No, it didnâ€™t make me mad but 
			Iâ€™m not going to let nobody draw down on me and my life is in 
			danger.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			So you werenâ€™t made [sic] at 
			him, you werenâ€™t outraged at him, you were just trying to defend 
			yourself, thatâ€™s your testimony?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Exactly.
 
		
		
			. . . 
 
			 
		
		
			Q:  
			How many steps did [Pollard] get 
			towards you before you dropped him?
 
		
		
			A: 
			About three or four.
		
		
			. . . 
			 
		
		
			Q:  
			And then you dropped him.  
			He didnâ€™t have anything in his hands, did he?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Nah, but as he was walking he 
			was reaching in his waist.
 
		
		
			Q:  
			Did he have anything in his 
			hands?
 
		
		
			A: 
			I couldnâ€™t see his hands.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Did you ever see his hands?
 
		
		
			A:  
			How could I?
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Did you ever see anything in his 
			hands?
 
		
		
			A: 
			No.  
		
	

Jackson was shot three times and Pollard was shot nine times.Â  Twenty-seven cartridges were
  recovered from the scene. Twenty-one were determined to have been fired from Cleaâ€™s gun.Â  The remaining six cartridges, though inconclusive, were the proper
  caliber for the same gun.Â  No weapons were found in the yard or in any
  vehicles.Â  Gunshot residue testing on Pollardâ€™s right hand indicated lead
  counts higher than would be expected had he fired a gun.Â  The SLED technician
  found it more consistent with a hand being on the muzzle end of a gun.Â  From
  the residue found on Jacksonâ€™s hand, the technician reasoned he either could
  have fired a gun or a gun was fired in his vicinity.Â  Testing of the shoebox
  was positive suggesting a gun had been placed in the box after being fired or
  that the box was open when a gun was fired nearby.Â   
Defense
  counsel requested a charge on voluntary manslaughter arguing the appearance of
  danger or the gesture of reaching for a weapon can adequately provide the
  necessary provocation.Â  The State objected stating no evidence showed sudden
  heat of passion or sufficient legal provocation.Â  After the trial judge
  considered the issue and reviewed the case law overnight, he ruled against the
  request finding no sudden heat of passion.Â  He explained:

	[F]or the Court to charge voluntary
  manslaughter, the law requires a sudden heat of passion brought about upon
  sufficient legal provocation.
	I find
  in this instance that the evidence does not support a charge of voluntary
  manslaughter.Â  That the evidence presented by the Defense best supports a
  self-defense charge in that there is no evidence of any sudden heat of
  passion.Â  That the case law required some degree of assault, and in addition to
  that, something that might have provoked the killing.
	That in this
  case, at best, the Defendantâ€™s testimony concerning the â€“ what he thought was a
  presence of a gun, indicates possibly some provocation but it does not conjure
  up any sudden heat of passion.Â  That the prior incidents between parties could
  not create a sudden heat of passion, but any passion regarding that, in
  addition to the Defendantâ€™s testimony about firing the shots regarding warning
  the Defendant [sic] or something of that nature, in and of itself does not
  indicate any sudden heat of passion and Iâ€™m not going to charge manslaughter.Â  
	

STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
The
  law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.Â  State
    v. Childers, 373 S.C. 367, 373, 645 S.E.2d 233, 235 (2006); State v.
      Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101, 525 S.E.2d 511, 512 (2000).Â  â€œDue process requires
  that a lesser included offense be charged when the evidence warrants it but
  only if the evidence would permit a jury rationally to find the defendant
  guilty of the lesser offense.â€Â  State v. Small, 307 S.C. 92, 94, 413
  S.E.2d 870, 871 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œIn determining whether the evidence requires
  a charge on voluntary manslaughter, this Court must view the facts in the light
  most favorable to the defendant.Â Â  Childers, 373 S.C. at 373, 645 S.E.2d
  at 235.Â  To justify a courtâ€™s eliminating the offense of manslaughter, it
  should clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce
  the crime from murder to manslaughter.Â  Id.Â   
DISCUSSION
Clea
  argues he was entitled to a charge of voluntary manslaughter given the facts of
  this case.Â  We disagree.Â   
â€œVoluntary
  manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in the sudden heat of
  passion upon sufficient legal provocation. Both heat of passion and sufficient
  legal provocation must be present at the time of the killing.â€Â  State v.
    Smith, 363 S.C. 111, 609 S.E.2d 528 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v.
      Cooley, 342 S.C. 63, 67, 536 S.E.2d 666, 668 (2000)).Â  â€œThe sudden heat of
  passion, upon sufficient legal provocation, which mitigates a felonious killing
  to manslaughter, while it need not dethrone reason entirely, or shut out
  knowledge and volition, must be such as would naturally disturb the sway of
  reason, and render the mind of an ordinary person incapable of cool reflection,
  and produce what, according to human experience, may be called an
  uncontrollable impulse to do violence.â€Â  State v. Walker, 324 S.C. 257,
  260, 478 S.E.2d 280, 281 (1996) (citing State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 474
  S.E.2d 430 (1996)).Â  When there is no evidence of sudden heat of passion upon
  sufficient legal provocation, the courtâ€™s refusal to instruct the jury on
  voluntary manslaughter is proper.Â  Id.
Viewing
  the evidence in the light most favorable to Clea, we find he did not act in the
  sudden heat of passion. Â Clea testified that, in the moments before the
  shooting, he was â€œsuspicious,â€ walked away from the victims, stalled at his
  truck, negotiated with Jackson to come to his truck to speak, and asked to be
  allowed to leave.Â  We find these statements demonstrate cool reflection.Â  Clea explained
  he was â€œheated upâ€ by Jacksonâ€™s not showing his hands.Â  But, further
  strengthening our determination, he said he was â€œjust precautiousâ€ and not mad.Â 
  Although he said Pollard provoked him by reaching into his waist, he again asserted
  he was not mad but simply defending himself.Â  See State v. Walker,
  324 S.C. 257, 478 S.E.2d 280 (1996) (no sudden heat of passion where defendant
  tried to diffuse argument and give victim time to cool off); State v. Rogers,
  275 S.C. 485, 272 S.E.2d 792 (1980) (defendantâ€™s testimony he was not mad when
  he shot wife and stepdaughter, together with his insanity defense, precluded
  voluntary manslaughter charge); cf. State v. Wiggins, 330 S.C. 538, 500 S.E.2d 489 (1998) (evidence tended to show defendant acted in sudden heat of passion where he was in a heated argument
  with victim and feared for his life because victim threatened him); State v.
    Lowry, 315 S.C. 396, 434 S.E.2d 272 (1993) (holding a voluntary
  manslaughter charge was necessary where defendant and victim were in a heated
  argument and victim was about to initiate a physical encounter when shooting
  occurred); State v. Davis, 278 S.C. 544, 298 S.E.2d 778 (1983) (holding
  voluntary manslaughter charge was proper where a witness testified that
  defendant and victim had been fighting).
Because
  there is clearly no evidence to show Clea acted in the sudden heat of passion,
  we will not reach the issue of whether sufficient legal provocation existed.Â 
 
CONCLUSION
The
  trial judge properly found Clea did not act in the sudden heat of passion and
  did not err in refusing to charge the lesser included offense of voluntary
  manslaughter.Â  Accordingly, Cleaâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT AND WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of the Care and Treatment of Robert Lee Cogdill, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-553
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  December 14, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief for Capital Appeals Robert Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, Office
  of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert
  Lee Cogdill appeals the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to grant a directed verdict â€œon
  the charge that [he] was a sexually violent predator since there was no direct
  or substantial circumstantial evidence on a personal level, rather than as a
  matter of statistics, that [he] was likely to engage in acts of sexual violence
  if he was not confined to a secure facility for . . . long term care and
  treatment, particularly where the stateâ€™s expert did not conduct any testing on
  [him] before . . . rendering her general opinion.â€Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In
  1986, Cogdill plead guilty to committing a lewd act on a minor and was
  sentenced to five years probation.Â  In 1988, he plead guilty to two counts of
  first degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor and was sentenced to thirty
  years incarceration.Â  Prior to Cogdillâ€™s scheduled release date, the State of
  South Carolina filed a petition pursuant to the South Carolina Sexually Violent
  Predator Act, South Carolina Code section 44-48-100 (Supp. 2006), seeking to
  have Cogdill civilly committed for long term care and treatment as a sexually
  violent predator.
The
  matter was called for a jury trial on May 17, 2005.Â  Following the close of the
  Stateâ€™s case, Cogdillâ€™s attorney made a motion for a directed verdict.Â 
  Specifically, Cogdillâ€™s attorney argued that the testimony of the Stateâ€™s sole
  witness was not based on individual testing or observations of Cogdill and
  there was no evidence that Cogdill had â€œserious difficultyâ€ controlling his
  behavior as required by Kansas v. Crane, 534 U.S. 407, 122 S.Ct. 867
  (2002). Â The circuit court denied the motion for a directed verdict. At the
  conclusion of the trial, the jury found Cogdill was a sexually violent
  predator, and the trial judge, by order filed May 18, 2005, committed Cogdill
  to the custody of the South Carolina Department of Mental Health for long term
  control, care, and treatment.Â  Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
When reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict, this Court applies
  the same standard as the trial court. Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp.,
  361 S.C. 9, 27, 602 S.E.2d 772, 782 (2004). The Court is required to view the
  evidence and inferences that
  reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the non-moving
  party. Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 428, 567 S.E.2d 231, 237
  (2002). When deciding whether to grant or deny a
  directed verdict motion, the court is concerned only with the existence of
  evidence. Pond Place Partners v. Poole, Inc., 351 S.C. 1, 15, 567 S.E.2d
  881, 888 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The motion â€œshould be denied when either the
  evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.â€ McMillan
    v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 564, 626 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2006).Â  â€œWhen considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the
  appellate court has authority to decide credibility
  issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.â€ Â Harvey v.
    Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 308, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Cogdillâ€™s appeals the trial judgeâ€™s denial
  of his motion for a directed verdict.Â  Cogdill specifically argues that the
  evidence presented against him was insufficient given that the testimony of the
  Stateâ€™s sole witness was not based on individual testing or observations of him
  and there was no evidence that he had â€œserious difficultyâ€ controlling his
  behavior as required by Kansas v. Crane, 534 U.S. 407, 122 S.Ct. 867
  (2002).Â  We disagree.
the trial, Dr. Pamela Crawford, a psychiatrist from the South Carolina Department
  of Mental Health, testified as an expert witness for the State.Â  Dr. Crawford
  testified that she did not perform any psychological test on Cogdill but that
  she met with Cogdill and reviewed information about him contained in his case
  file.Â  Â Dr. Crawford testified that Cogdill suffers from pedophilia, which
  affects his likelihood to re-offend and that it was her opinion, to a
  reasonable degree of medical certainty, Cogdill qualified as a sexually violent
  predator.Â  She also testified that Cogdill has trouble controlling his behavior
  and that his lack of control was illustrated by the fact he had re-offended
  while on probation.Â  Dr. Crawford testified that if Cogdill was released
  without treatment, he would likely re-offend and prepubescent boys would be at
  risk. Â During cross examination, Cogdillâ€™s
  attorney thoroughly questioned Dr. Crawford on the methods she used and the
  fact no psychological testing
  was performed on Cogdill.  
The testimony of Dr. Crawford provides sufficient evidence to
  justify the trial judgeâ€™s denial of Cogdillâ€™s motion and satisfies the mandate
  of Crane.Â  See In re
    Care & Treatment of Harvey, 355
  S.C. 53, 59-61, 584 S.E.2d 893, 896-7 (2003) (stating that the requirements of the Sexually Violent Predator Act are the
  functional equivalent of the requirement in Crane and finding
  sufficient evidence where a psychiatrist testified she diagnosed the offender
  with pedophilia and the offender met the statutory definition of a sexually
  violent predator).Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the order of the trial judge is  
AFFIRMED.  
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ronald C.
      Harris, Appellant,
				v.
				Penn Warranty
      Corporation and West Main Automotive Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-554
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  December 14, 2007Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Ronald C. Harris, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Robert Charles Brown and J. Austin Hood, both of Columbia and Stephen
  Bucher, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Ronald C. Harris filed this action against Penn Warranty Corporation (Penn) and
  West Main Automotive (West Main) arising out of Harrisâ€™ purchase of an
  automobile.Â  Harris appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting a motion to compel
  settlement.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This action was settled on the record
  after Harris presented his case during a jury trial.Â  The trial court dismissed
  the action.[2]Â 
  Penn and West Main remitted the settlement checks to Harris.Â  Harris returned
  the checks and refused to honor the settlement.  
West Main and Penn moved to compel settlement.[3]Â 
  At the hearing on the motion, Harris argued that although he agreed to the
  settlement on the record, he misunderstood the procedural posture of the case
  and disagreed with his attorney regarding settlement.Â  The court granted the
  motion to compel settlement.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
Harris
  argues his attorney â€œentrappedâ€ him into making the settlement and the
  settlement is unfair.Â  â€œIt is a long-standing and well-settled rule that an
  attorney may settle litigation on behalf of his client and that the client is
  bound by his attorneyâ€™s settlement actions.â€Â  Motley v. Williams, 374
  S.C. 107, 111, 647 S.E.2d 244, 246 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  â€œAny communication failure or mistake on the part of an attorney
  is directly attributable to his client.â€Â  Id. at 112, 647 S.E.2d at 247.
At the hearing on
  the motion to compel settlement, the trial court reviewed the record and noted
  Harrisâ€™ agreement to the settlement.Â  The judge at the trial queried the
  attorneys and Harris himself to verify all issues were settled and then asked:Â 
  â€œMr. Harris, do you have any questions, sir, at all?â€Â  Harris asked about any
  possible counterclaims and was assured all potential counterclaims were also
  settled.Â  The trial court dismissed the action.Â  We find no error by the trial
  court in granting the motion to compel settlement.
Harris also argues
  the settlement documents contain stipulations that were not agreed upon on the
  record at the trial.Â  Harris does not explain this allegation and did not raise
  the issue to the trial court at the hearing on the motion to compel
  settlement.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 24, 602 S.E.2d 772,
  780 (2004) (stating an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the circuit
  court to be preserved).
Based on the
  foregoing, the order on appeal is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT,
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  For background facts, see this Courtâ€™s opinion
  at Harris v. Penn Warranty, Op. No. 2007-UP-00546 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Dec. 11, 2007).Â  
 
[3]  West Main filed the motion and Penn later joined
  in the motion.

				Ernest Matthew

Â H. E. Bonnoitt, Jr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-555
Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed December
  14, 2007Â Â Â  
REVERSED 



	
		
			
				David C. Shea and Rebecca Guental Fulmer, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
				C. Vance Stricklin, Jr. and Katherine Carruth Link, both of West Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: The
  family court judge granted Ernest Matthew West (Husband) and Mary Denise
  West (Wife) a divorce on the ground of one year continuous separation.Â  The
  judge granted Wife custody of the partiesâ€™ two minor children and granted
  Husband visitation rights.Â  In addition, the judge prohibited Husband from
  traveling with the children outside of the State of South Carolina during his
  visitation.Â  Husband appeals the travel restriction claiming the family court
  judge abused his discretion in failing to apply proper legal principles and
  imposing an unreasonable restriction contrary to the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â 
  We reverse.  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married on November
  18, 1992.Â  The parties had two children during their marriage, a daughter, now
  nine years old, and a son, now six years old.Â  During the early years of the
  marriage, Wife worked as a school teacher.Â  When the children were born, the
  parties agreed Wife would stop working and stay at home with the children.Â Â Â  
 
In 2002, Husbandâ€™s employer, Saftey Kleen Corporation, went
  bankrupt and closed its Columbia office.Â  The employer offered Husband a
  position in the companyâ€™s Dallas, Texas office.Â  Husband moved to Texas, and Wife remained in South Carolina with the children.Â  After one year in Texas, Husband moved to Miami, Florida, to pursue a new employment opportunity.Â 
 
Husbandâ€™s
  absence put a strain on the marital relationship, and on February 23, 2004,
  Wife brought an action for separate maintenance, custody of the children, and
  child support.Â  Husband filed an answer and counterclaim requesting the courtâ€™s
  approval to reside separate and apart from Wife and seeking joint custody of
  the children.Â  At the temporary hearing, the family court judge awarded sole
  temporary custody of the children to Wife and awarded Husband visitation
  rights.Â  Because Husband was still living in Miami, Husbandâ€™s visitation was
  limited to his parentsâ€™ home in Kershaw, South Carolina.Â  During the
  separation, Husband traveled to South Carolina every other weekend to visit
  with the children.Â  Eventually, Husband purchased and moved into a home in Greenville,   South Carolina, within fifteen miles of Wife and children.Â 
 
At the
  final hearing, Wife moved to supplement her pleadings and seek a divorce on the
  ground of one year separation.Â  Additionally, Wife sought supervised visitation
  for Husband because of his: (1) controlling nature; (2) unstable lifestyle; (3)
  temper; and (4) credibility.Â  Further, Wife expressed concern Husband was
  involved in a homosexual affair and believed Husband presented a threat of harm
  to the children.Â  Husband denied the adulterous affair throughout most of the
  divorce litigation.Â  It was not until a week before the final hearing that
  Husband admitted he had an affair.Â   
Husband admitted he had not been honest about his adulterous
  conduct during the divorce proceedings and regretted not disclosing it earlier
  in the litigation.Â  Husband stated he came forward shortly before the hearing
  because he â€œdid not want to finish whatever happens with this on an untruthful
  note.â€Â  Husband stated he never had, and did not intend to have, his children
  around his paramour.Â  He also stated he had no problem with an order
  prohibiting him from bringing the children around his paramour.Â   
The judge awarded full custody of the children to Wife and granted
  Husband a â€œstandardâ€ unsupervised visitation schedule.Â  In addition, the judge
  imposed a restriction on Husband that he was not to remove the children from
  the State of South Carolina during the exercise of his visitation.Â 
  Additionally, the judge â€œrestrained [Husband] from exposing the children to any
  non-spouse romantic companion or relationship.â€[1]Â   
Husband
  filed a motion seeking to alter or amend the final divorce decree to allow
  Husband to have visitation outside the confines of South Carolina and the award
  of attorney fees.Â  The judge denied the motion, concluding that â€œrestricting
  [Husbandâ€™s] visitation to the State of South Carolina is reasonable and
  protects the . . . children.â€Â  This appeal followed.[2]
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the
  family court, the appellate court has the authority to correct errors of law
  and to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102
  (2005); Miller v. Miller, 299 S.C. 307, 311, 384 S.E.2d 715, 717
  (1989).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require this court to
  disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302,
  307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 149 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the
  family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position
  to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their
  testimony.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623
  (2003).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband claims the
  family court judge erred in imposing a travel restriction on his visitation
  because it was based solely on the judgeâ€™s moral condemnation of Husbandâ€™s
  lifestyle absent any evidence his conduct adversely affected the welfare of his
  children.[3]Â 
  We agree.Â   
When
  awarding visitation, the paramount consideration is the welfare of the child.Â  Woodall
    v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 12, 471 S.E.2d 154, 158 (1996).Â  A parentâ€™s
  morality, while a proper factor for consideration, is limited in its force to
  what relevancy it has, either directly or indirectly to the welfare of the
  child.Â  Davenport v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d
  228, 230 (1975); Stroman v. Williams, 291 S.C. 376, 378, 353 S.E.2d 704,
  705 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  In Stroman, this court
  recognized homosexuality, in and of itself, is not a bar to custody or
  reasonable rights of visitation.Â  Stroman, 291 S.C. at 379, 353
  S.E.2d at 706 (citing Marriage of Cabalquinto, 100 Wash.2d 325, 669 P.2d
  886 (1983)).Â  Nor are a parentâ€™s sexual indiscretions a proper consideration
  unless they are shown to adversely affect the welfare of the child.Â  Id. (citing Guinan v. Guinan, 102 A.D.2d 963, 477 N.Y.S.2d 830) (1984)).Â  In
  Judge Sandersâ€™ concurrence he explained: â€œNo moral judgment by us has been
  necessary because there is no evidence that [the parentâ€™s] lifestyle had any
  relevancy to the welfare of the child.â€Â  Id. at 381, 353 S.E.2d 706-07
  (C.J. Sanders concurring).Â  Furthermore, while the issue of visitation rests
  largely within the discretion of the trial judge, visitation is not to be used
  to penalize or reward a parent for his or her conduct.Â  Stroman, 291
  S.C. at 378, 353 S.E.2d at 705.Â  We are bound by this courtâ€™s prior precedent.
In deciding to impose restrictions on Husbandâ€™s visitation, the
  judge â€œ[felt] it necessary to impose specific restrictions related to the
  [Husbandâ€™s] actionsâ€ because he did not condone Husbandâ€™s alternative
  lifestyle.Â  The judge acknowledged the travel restriction was an
  â€œunusual restriction, . . . based on the [Husbandâ€™s] self-indulgent and deviant
  lifestyleâ€ but â€œnecessary to protect the morality of the children.â€Â  The judge
  further iterated:

	The [Husband] chose an inappropriate relationship over his
  marriage.Â  He admitted that he undertook a covenant with his wife and with a
  higher power which was broken.Â  Based on his willingness to break this covenant
  and pursue an adulterous relationship . . . [Husbandâ€™s] visitation should be
  confined to the State of South Carolina to protect the best interest of the
  minor children.Â  

In the denial of Husbandâ€™s motion to alter or amend, the judge provided
  further reasoning for the travel restriction.Â  The judge reasoned the proximity
  would encourage compliance and found Husband would be â€œless likely to be
  distracted by the pursuit of his other relationship, and as a result, the
  children are more likely to receive quality time with their father.â€Â  The judge
  concluded, â€œ[i]f [Husband] is allowed to take the children out of state, he is
  more likely to expose the children to a harmful situation including exposure to
  his paramour who lives out of state.â€Â  
It is clear the judge imposed a visitation restriction based on
  moral considerations and his disapproval of Husbandâ€™s adulterous conduct.Â  We
  find it was proper for the judge to consider Husbandâ€™s morality as a factor in
  determining visitation rights. Â However, this consideration must be limited to
  the extent it was shown to adversely impact upon the welfare of the children. Â We
  are not asked here to condone conduct which may not be condoned by segments of
  society; instead, we are not only asked whether the parent has been
  inappropriately penalized for such conduct, but also, and more precisely,
  whether the childrenâ€™s interaction with a biological parent may be so
  restricted as a consequence thereof contrary to their best interests. After a
  review of the evidence, we find there was no evidence that Husbandâ€™s conduct
  endangered or adversely affected the welfare of the children.
In this case the appointed Guardian ad Litem (GAL) submitted a
  written report and testified at the hearing.Â  In her report, the GAL expressed
  concern with Husbandâ€™s lack of candor concerning his sexuality, but found no
  evidence Husband had the children around any paramour or subjected the children
  to an alternative lifestyle.Â  Further, the GAL stated â€œI have found no reason
  to believe that [Husband] has ever done anything to the children that would
  place them in danger or that that he would do so in the future.â€Â  She
  concluded, â€œI believe it would be in the best interest of the children that the
  children have contact with both parents on a regular basis â€¦ [and] I believe it
  is in the best interest of the children that both parents have time alone with
  the children.â€Â  At the hearing, the GAL stated she saw no reason to limit
  Husbandâ€™s visitation and found nothing to indicate the children would be at
  risk if Husband traveled with the children out of South Carolina.Â Â Â Â   
Dr.
  Watson, the expert clinical psychologist appointed by the court to determine
  whether Husband was a danger to his children, also testified at the hearing.Â 
  Dr. Watson testified Husband was not a threat to his children and did not need
  to be supervised around his children.Â  He acknowledged Husbandâ€™s deception and
  expressed some concern, but did not believe Husbandâ€™s lying presented a threat
  of harm to the children.Â  Dr. Watson did not recommend supervision for the
  Husband.Â Â Â   
Moreover,
  the judgeâ€™s initial evaluation specifically found no evidence Husband exposed
  the children to the relationship, encouraged the children to pursue â€œa deviant
  or alternative lifestyle,â€ or that his lifestyle would lead to â€œother conduct
  detrimental to the children.â€  
Wife contends the restriction was not imposed as a penalty for
  Husbandâ€™s adulterous affair, but was based on the judgeâ€™s concern for the
  welfare of the children.Â  Wife avers the judge grounded his restriction on
  genuine concerns of Husbandâ€™s character and behavior, including his controlling
  nature, unstable lifestyle, temper, and lack of credibility.Â  She argues these
  concerns were apart from his adulterous conduct.Â   
In determining visitation in the final divorce decree, the judge specifically
  addressed each of Wifeâ€™s concerns about Husbandâ€™s character and behavior.Â  The
  judge concluded the evidence of Husbandâ€™s controlling nature, unstable
  lifestyle, temper, or lack of credibility did not rise to the level of
  requiring supervised visitation.Â  Accordingly, the judge found no reason to
  require supervised visitation and thereby granted Husband a â€œstandardâ€
  unsupervised visitation schedule.Â  Clearly, the judge did not find sufficient
  evidence that Husbandâ€™s character or conduct raised sufficient concern for the
  welfare of the children such as to require supervised visitation.Â  Even as to
  Husbandâ€™s untimely disclosure of his conduct, Â the trial judge found that while
  Husband had been untruthful throughout the litigation and had created an
  atmosphere of distrust, visitation should not be used to reward or penalize a
  parent. Â Thus, we find these aspects of Husbandâ€™s character were of concern
  only insofar as they related to the fear that Husbandâ€™s conduct would endanger
  the children.Â  It is apparent that, but for Husbandâ€™s prior sexual misconduct,
  the judge would not have concluded the children needed â€œprotection.â€Â  The
  record simply does not support Wifeâ€™s argument the travel restriction was based
  on genuine concerns about Husbandâ€™s character and behavior, apart from his
  adulterous conduct.
CONCLUSION
Based on this courtâ€™s prior precedent, we respectfully conclude
  the judge improperly imposed a travel restriction on Husbandâ€™s visitation with
  his children.Â  Absent any evidence that Husbandâ€™s adulterous conduct endangered
  or adversely impacted the welfare of his children, we hold the judge
  impermissibly penalized Husband for his conduct and that it is not in the best
  interests of the children to uphold the travel restriction.Â  Accordingly, we
  reverse the travel restriction on Husbandâ€™s visitation.Â  In light of our
  disposition, we need not address Husbandâ€™s remaining issues.Â  See Whiteside
    v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340-41, 428 S.E.2d
  886, 889 (1993) (appellate court need not address a remaining issue when
  resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â Â Â   
REVERSED.
HUFF and PIEPER,
  JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur. 

[1] Although the appointed Guardian ad Litem recommended
  both parents be enjoined and restrained from bringing overnight guests with
  whom he or she is having a romantic relationship when the children are present,
  the judge only imposed this restriction on Husband.Â   
[2] The only issue on appeal is the travel restriction imposed
  on Husbandâ€™s visitation.Â   
[3] Husband claims, in his reply brief, that the travel
  restriction is materially distinct from the supervised visitation requested by
  Wife in her complaint.Â  Husband contends the judge erred in awarding relief not
  contemplated by the pleadings.Â  We find this argument is not preserved for our
  review.Â  First, it was not raised to the family court judge during the trial or
  in Husbandâ€™s motion to alter or amend.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly
    Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that issues
  must be raised and ruled upon in the trial court to be preserved for appellate
  review).Â  Additionally, Husband raised the argument for the first time in his
  reply brief.Â  See Crawford v. Henderson, 356 S.C. 389, 409, 589
  S.E.2d 204, 215 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding appellant could not raise additional
  arguments in reply brief because it was not addressed in initial brief).

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
 THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
         RV Resort and Yacht Club Owners Association, Inc., Jean Littell,
          Kathy Fudge, Dwight Blakeslee, Herb Hook, Stan Bronson, Peg Bender, and
          Claudette Delpesco, on behalf of all members of the Association similarly
          situated Individually, Respondents,
         v.
         BillyBobâ€™s Marina, Inc., d/b/a Outdoor RV Resort and Yacht Club, Appellant.
      
    
  


 Appeal From Beaufort County
  Â Thomas Kemmerlin, Special Referee

 Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-556
  Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed December
  14, 2007

 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
        John R. C. Bowen, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â   In
  this action to enforce covenants, BillyBobâ€™s Marina, Inc., d/b/a Outdoor RV Resort and Yacht Club
    (BillyBob), appeals the special refereeâ€™s order awarding, inter alia,
    damages and attorneyâ€™s fees to the RV Resort and Yacht Club Owners Association,
    Inc. (the Association).[1]
      We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
Outdoor
  Resorts RV Resort and Yacht Club (the Development) is a recreational vehicle (RV)
  resort and marina located on Jenkins Island in Beaufort County.Â  From the Developmentâ€™s
  inception in 1981, it has consisted of several separate areas.Â  One of these
  areas is the Marina, which has 110 slips, a fuel dock, a launching ramp, a bath
  house, fuel storage facilities, an access road, a marina office, and several
  parking spaces.Â  The Marina is a completely separate entity from the rest of
  the Development.Â  Another area is the Resort, which includes 200 lots with
  parking pads for RVs (lots), swimming pools, tennis courts, a playground, a
  yacht club/clubhouse building, roads and open space, a maintenance area, and
  utilities, including a sewage treatment facility.Â  Many of the lots were owned
  by individuals.Â  A third area is a real estate and rental management business
  (Rental Office), which includes a building, check-in areas, and parking spaces.Â 
  Outdoor Resort R.V. Resort and Yacht Club, a South Carolina General
  Partnership, developed the Resort and owned the Marina and Rental Office.Â  In
  June 1981, the â€œDeclaration of Covenants and Restrictions for Outdoor Resorts,
  R.V. Resort and Yacht Club and Provisions for the R.V. Resort and Yacht Club
  Ownersâ€™ Association, Inc.â€Â  (Covenants) were recorded.Â  Â 
The
  Covenants provide Developer has the exclusive right to rent lots belonging to
  the individual owners within the Resort when not occupied by the owner and his
  or her guest at the scheduled rate promulgated by Developer.Â  The Covenants
  further provide Developer shall retain fifty percent â€œof rental collected on
  any Lotâ€ and remit the remaining fifty percent to the lot owner.Â  The
  definition section of the Covenants does not contain a definition relating to
  rent or rental.Â  Â Â 
Article
  VIII, Section 8.11 of the Covenants provides: â€œOther reasonable rules and
  regulations governing use and occupancy and which do not alter or are not in
  contravention of any of the foregoing provisions may be made and amended from
  time to time by the Association, without the prior written consent of the
  Developer . . ..â€Â  From 1981 to 1999 the Developer rented lots, splitting the
  rental fee 50/50 with the owners and collecting an additional fee of $2.00 for
  the use of electricity.Â  The Developer paid the electricity fee directly to the
  owner of the lot (electricity charge).Â  In 1999, Dwight Blakeslee, as President
  of the Association, requested an increase in rental rates.Â  First, Blakeslee
  requested Developer collect an additional $1.00 per night as a â€œroad taxâ€ to
  reserve for road resurfacing.Â  Next, Blakeslee requested the electricity charge
  be increased $1.00 per night to $3.00 due to the increase in size and
  technology of the vehicles renting lots.Â  On June 23, 1999, Developer agreed to
  the Associationâ€™s proposal. 
On
  July 7, 1999, Blakeslee sent a letter on behalf of the Association to Linda
  Higgins, the Rental Manager of the Developer, accepting Higginsâ€™ suggestion to
  implement the new charges beginning September 15, 1999.Â  The letter also
  requested, in the event of a sale of Developerâ€™s interest, â€œthe agreed upon
  rate increase and the allocation of those funds be made known to the buyer so
  that there will be no question as to the validity of the rate change.â€ 
On August
  31, 1999, BillyBob bought the Marina and rental management businesses, along with
  real estate Developer owned within the Development, Developerâ€™s rights to rent
  lots, and the Lease.Â  The electricity charge was collected and remitted to the
  lot owners for a short time following BillyBobâ€™s purchase.Â  
On
  October 17, 1999, BillyBob informed the Association by letter that it was
  cancelling the $3 electricity charge effective October 31, 1999.Â  BillyBob wanted
  to increase the nightly rental rate from $26.00 to $32.00.[2]Â 
    BillyBob sent a second letter the same day stating it would charge the $1.00
    per night road tax retroactively from August 31, 1999, but only if the Association
    would pass a resolution or amendment committing the Association to maintaining
    and repairing Developerâ€™s roads in the same manner and state of repair as the
    Associationâ€™s roads.
The Association
  rejected BillyBobâ€™s demand to undertake maintenance and repairs of Developerâ€™s
  roads and objected to BillyBobâ€™s refusal to honor the previous Developerâ€™s
  commitment to collect the $3.00 electricity charge and $1.00 road tax. 
BillyBob
  initiated its proposed changes and further initiated a telephone fee, charging
  renters $2.00 for lots with telephone service and paying the owners $1.00 of
  this charge.Â  In addition, BillyBob claimed a right of first refusal on lot
  sales and established numerous new restrictions on the ownersâ€™ use of their
  lots including restrictions on owners leaving vehicles on the lots and renting
  to families with children.Â  
The Association and
  several lot owners filed this action alleging, inter alia, BillyBobâ€™s
  violated the Covenants by failing to collect and remit all of the charges.Â  BillyBob
  counterclaimed asserting numerous violations of the Covenants including
  permanent residents living on their lots in the Resort.Â  Following a bench
  trial, the referee found the Covenants governed, the Association had the
  authority to adopt and modify rules and regulations as long as not in contravention
  of the Covenants, and BillyBob had no right to modify the Covenants or
  promulgate rules in contravention thereof. Â The referee found BillyBob violated
  the Covenants by failing to collect the road tax, and failing to remit all of
  the money collected for electricity and telephone charges.Â  The referee also
  found BillyBob violated the Covenants in numerous other manners, including
  allowing marina guests to use the Associationâ€™s common areas and prohibiting guests
  with children to rent waterfront lots.Â  The referee ordered an accounting to
  determine sums due the Association.Â  The referee also found neither party entitled
  to attorneyâ€™s fees for the issues determined to date.Â  
After
  a hearing on the accounting and the remaining issues, the referee awarded the
  Association $48,447.50 for the road tax fund, $145,831.50 for electricity
  charges, and $1,048.50 for telephone charges.Â  Additionally, the referee awarded attorneyâ€™s fees of $52,212.50 and costs of
  $16,379.05.Â  BillyBob appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This court recently addressed the standard of review
  in an action to enforce restrictive covenants:

  The character of an action as legal or equitable depends on the
    relief sought. Compare Oâ€™Shea v. Lesser, 308 S.C. 10, 14, 416 S.E.2d 629, 631
      (1992) (holding an
    action for breach of restrictive covenants was at law,
    because relief sought was general damages for loss of
    view and invasion of privacy) [with] Kneale v. Bonds, 317 S.C.
    262, 265, 452 S.E.2d 840, 841 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is
    in equity.â€); see also S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville,
    345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001) (holding an action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is
    an equitable action). . .. Â [If
    the] action is one to enforce restrictive covenants by
    injunction, it is in equity, and we may find facts in accordance with our own
    view of the evidence.Â  Brenco v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 363 S.C. 136,
    142, 609 S.E.2d 531, 534 (Ct. App. 2005). Â 

Cedar Cove
  Homeowners Assâ€™n v. DiPietro, 368 S.C. 254, 258, 628 S.E.2d 284, 286 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  If the
  action for breach of covenants is at law, we will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s
  findings unless they are unsupported by the evidence.Â  Oâ€™Shea v. Lesser,
  308 S.C. 10, 14, 416 S.E.2d 629, 631 (1992).
LAW/ANALYSIS


I.Â  Covenants
BillyBob contends the referee erred in finding it was
  required to collect the road tax for the benefit of the Association and to
  collect and remit the full electricity and telephone charges.Â  We disagree.
â€œRestrictive
  covenants are contractual in nature, so that the paramount rule of construction
  is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the parties as determined from
  the whole document.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001). â€œThe language of a
  restrictive covenant is to be construed according to the plain and ordinary
  meaning attributed to it at the time of execution.â€Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369
  S.C. 160, 166, 631 S.E.2d 539, 542 (2006). Â 
BillyBob contends
  the charges constitute rent, which he has the exclusive right to set, and thus,
  they are subject to the equal division between BillyBob and the lot owners.Â  BillyBob
  relies in part on the Associationâ€™s letter discussing the changes in which they
  refer to the charges as part of the increase in â€œrental rates.â€Â  However, as
  the letter described, these charges would not operate as the rental rate did, because
  the charges would pass directly to the lot owners instead of being subject to a
  split.Â  The Covenants grant the Association the right to promulgate rules and
  regulations without BillyBobâ€™s permission.Â  We find BillyBob was required to
  collect the charges on behalf of the Association and therefore affirm the
  refereeâ€™s findings on this issue.
II.Â  Permanent Resident 
BillyBob
  next contends the referee erred in failing to find Dwight Blakeslee, a lot
  owner, was permanently residing on his lot in violation of the Covenants.Â  We
  disagree.
Article
  VIII, section 8.1, of the Covenants state: â€œIt is the specific intent of this
  Declaration to create and maintain a lu[x]ury resort for recreational vehicles
  and to prohibit permanent or semi-permanent structures as well as any structure
  or vehicle which is used as, or designed for use as, permanent living quarters
  on any Lot.â€Â  The section further provides: â€œLot Owners . . . are prohibited
  from erecting or placing on any Lot any permanent or semi-permanent structure
  or any vehicle which is designed as permanent living quarters . . ..â€ 
BillyBob
  contends Blakesleeâ€™s claim of the homestead exemption for tax purposes
  indicates Blakeslee is a permanent resident.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  12-37-250(A)(1)(Supp. 2006) (providing, for certain classes of people: â€œThe
  first fifty thousand dollars of the fair market value of the dwelling place of
  a person is exempt from county, municipal, school, and special assessment real
  estate property taxes. . ..â€).Â  â€œDwelling placeâ€ is defined as the â€œpermanent
  home and legal residence of the applicant.â€Â  Id. at Â§12-37-250(A)(5).Â  
However,
  there is other evidence in the record that Blakeslee is not a permanent
  resident.Â  Jean Littell, a long time owner and board member, testified
  Blakeslee was not a permanent resident.Â  She testified he travels between three
  and six months out of the year and when he travels he usually takes his RV with
  him.Â  BillyBob did not present any testimony that Blakeslee actually
  permanently resided on his lot.Â  We find no reversible error in the refereeâ€™s
  finding that Blakeslee was not a permanent resident.
III.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
BillyBob
  maintains the referee erred in awarding fees and costs to the Association
  instead of BillyBob.Â Â  We agree the Association was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s
  fees.
â€œAn
  award of attorneysâ€™ fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be
  overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€ Â Donahue v. Donahue,
  299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion
  occurs when the decision is controlled by some error of law or is based on
  findings of fact that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96,
  97 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Generally, attorneyâ€™s fees are
  not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.Â  Baron Data Sys.,
    Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 383, 377 S.E.2d 296, 297 (1989).Â  â€œRestrictive
  covenants are contractual in nature.â€Â  Hoffman v. Cohen, 262 S.C. 71,
  75, 202 S.E.2d 363, 365 (1974).
The Covenants and the Lease
  allow for the recovery of attorneyâ€™s fees for the prevailing party.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court has defined a
  prevailing party as â€œone who successfully prosecutes the action or successfully
  defends against it, prevailing on the main issue, even though not to the extent
  of the original contention [and] is the one in whose favor the decision or
  verdict is rendered and judgment entered.â€ Â Heath
    v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182-83, 394 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1990)
  (alteration in original).
In its
  first order, the referee found because each of the parties had prevailed on
  some issues, neither was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The referee stated: â€œI
  will consider attorney[â€™]s fees on the remainder of the case after a hearing on
  the merits of the remaining issues.â€Â  The remaining issues involved an
  accounting and allegations by the Association of fraud by BillyBob.Â  In the
  final hearing, the referee found no fraud by BillyBob but awarded attorneyâ€™s
  fees to the Association of $52,212.50 and costs of $16,379.05.Â  Furthermore, the referee failed to make specific findings in support of the
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  â€œOur case law and
  court rules make clear that when a contract or statute authorizes an award of
  attorneyâ€™s fees, the trial court must make specific findings of fact on the
  record for each of the required factors to be considered.â€Â  Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 646, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534-35 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Accordingly,
  we reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
BillyBob also
  contends it should have received attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  BillyBob likewise prevailed
  only on some of the issues and the record does not support an award of
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the referee did not err in failing to award BillyBob
  attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED IN PART
  AND REVERSED IN PART.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Several individual members of the Association
  are named plaintiffs.Â  We refer to all plaintiffs collectively as the
  Association.
[2] At the time of purchase, the rental rate was

  electricity charge for a total of $16.00 per night.Â  Developer received

title: State v. Judith Law
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Judith A. Law, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-557
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  December 14, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Â Judith
  A. Law appeals the probation courtâ€™s order holding her in contempt.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On September 15, 2005, Law was brought before the court for a
  probation revocation hearing.Â  Law admitted she had violated the terms of her
  probation.Â  The probation court issued a written order that found Law had
  violated the conditions of her probation, revoked Lawâ€™s probation, and re-instated
  her suspended five year sentence.Â  Following sentencing, a probation agent
  presented a Form 9 (revocation order) to Law for her signature.Â  Law signed the
  revocation order â€œKiss My Assâ€ and instructed the probation agent to give the
  revocation order to the judge.Â  The probation agent complied with Lawâ€™s
  instruction, and the judge scheduled a contempt hearing for later that day. Â Â Â 
Following the hearing, the judge prepared a written order which
  stated that Law had signed the revocation order â€œKiss My Assâ€ and requested the
  revocation order be taken to the judge and that her request had been fulfilled.Â 
  The judgeâ€™s order also stated that Law had been held in contempt for her
  conduct.Â  Â Law appeals the probation courtâ€™s order holding her in contempt.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
All
  courts have inherent power to punish for contempt. Curlee v. Howle, 277
  S.C. 377, 382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 918 (1982). Â This power is essential to the
  preservation of order in judicial proceedings and the due administration of
  justice. Â Id.Â  The â€œdetermination
  of contempt ordinarily resides in the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€ Â State
    v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  An
  appellate court â€œshould reverse a decision regarding contempt only if it is
  without evidentiary support or the trial judge has abused his discretion.â€ Â Durlach
    v. Durlach, 359 S.C. 64, 70, 596 S.E.2d 908, 912 (2004) (internal quotation
  and citation omitted).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is
  controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of
  fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€ Â Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73,
  587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Law argues the probation court erred by holding her â€œin contempt,
  and imposing a ninety day additional sentence, where the record fails to
  disclose the nature of the alleged contemptuous conduct, and whether it
  allegedly occurred in the presence of the court or outside the presence of the
  court.â€Â  We disagree.
Clearly, the alleged contemptuous conduct was signing the
  revocation order â€œKiss My Assâ€ and instructing that the revocation order,
  signed in that manner, be given to the judge.Â  The revocation order is included
  in the record and is signed â€œKiss My Assâ€.Â  During the contempt hearing, the judge
  stated the probation agent brought the revocation order back to her.Â 
  Accordingly, the record clearly shows Lawâ€™s contemptuous conduct.  
We now turn to Lawâ€™s argument that the record fails to disclose
  whether the contemptuous conduct occurred in the presence of the court or
  outside the presence of the court.Â  â€œSouth Carolina courts have always taken a liberal and expansive view of the â€˜presenceâ€™ and
  â€˜courtâ€™ requirements. This Stateâ€™s courts have held the â€˜presence of the courtâ€™
  extends beyond the mere physical presence of the judge or the courtroom to
  encompass all elements of the system.â€ State v. Kennerly, 337 S.C. 617,
  620, 524 S.E.2d 837, 838 (1999).Â   
No matter where Law signed the revocation order, her conduct was
  in the presence of the judge when she requested the revocation order be given
  to the judge and the judge reviewed the revocation order after receiving it.Â 
  Given the record before us, it was clearly within the probation courtâ€™s
  discretion to hold Law in contempt of court.
CONCLUSION
For
  the reason stated above, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Department of
      Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Nancy N., Don N.,
      James B., and Heath S., Defendants,  
				of whom Nancy N.
          and Don N. are Appellants.
				In the interests of: K.G. (DOB: 09/06/94) and J.G. (DOB: 2/12/97),
  minors under the age of 18. 
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Timothy M. Cain, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-558
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  December 14, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William E. Phillips, of Anderson, for 
				Appellants.
				Dottie C. Ingram, of Anderson, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Nancy
  N. (Mother) and Don N. (Stepfather) appeal an order of the family court which,
  among other things, refused to allow the minor children K.G. and J.G. to return
  to Motherâ€™s custody and permanently restrained Stepfather from contact with either
  child.Â  Specifically, Mother and Stepfather argue the family court erred in
  admitting J.G.â€™s out-of-court statements alleging sexual abuse by Stepfather. Â We
  affirm.[1]  
FACTS
K.G. and J.G. were
  placed in emergency protective custody on August 18, 2005 when the children
  were ages ten and eight, respectively.Â  When the children were removed from
  their home, J.G had a black eye and bruises on his neck.Â  Stepfather told law
  enforcement that he had lifted J.G. by his neck.Â  Â At the probable cause
  hearing, the family court found Stepfather had physically abused J.G. and
  Mother failed to protect her children from abuse and neglect. Â DSS was given
  legal custody of the children, and they were placed in foster care.Â  Soon after
  J.G.â€™s placement, he attempted a sexual act on another child in the foster
  home. Â J.G.â€™s disruptive behavior resulted in his relocation in seven foster
  care settings before being transferred to York Place, a residential treatment
  facility for emotionally disturbed children.  
Prior
  to the merits hearing, DSS gave Mother and Stepfather notice of its intent to
  present testimony of J.G.â€™s out-of-court statements alleging sexual abuse by
  Stepfather.Â  At the hearing, Mother and Stepfather objected to these
  out-of-court statements, but the family court allowed them pursuant to section
  19-1-180 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).
Nicholas
  Godfrey, J.G.â€™s former case manager, testified that he had asked J.G. about his
  sexual behavior toward the other child in foster care. Â J.G. said Stepfather
  had engaged in the same sexual behavior with him.Â  Godfrey found the report to
  be credible because J.G. cried uncontrollably and appeared traumatized as they
  discussed the alleged sexual abuse by Stepfather. Â Trinity Sands, a forensic
  interviewer, testified she conducted an assessment of J.G. the week following
  J.Gâ€™s disclosure to Godfrey. Â Sands considered J.G.â€™s statements alleging
  sexual abuse by Stepfather to be credible based on the level of detail J.G.
  provided.
After
  his transfer to York Place in February 2006, J.G. received daily behavior
  management therapy sessions with licensed social worker, Catherine Jones. Â Jones
  stated J.G. initially exhibited aggressive behaviors with adults, sexual acting
  out with children, and self-harming behaviors.Â  However, after a year of
  intensive individual counseling, group therapy, and medication for a mood
  disorder, J.G. had progressed greatly. Â He had recently returned to public
  school and would soon be moved to a therapeutic foster home. Â According to Jones,
  J.G. would be severely traumatized if required to testify in any setting about
  the alleged sexual abuse, and he could potentially regress.Â  Additionally, she
  testified that J.G. associated everything about the court with talking to a
  judge, and he had told her â€œhe did not want to talk to the Judge.â€  
DSS
  foster care manager, Dani Lawson, testified that Mother still did not believe
  Stepfather had sexually abused J.G. Â Although Mother stated she believed
  something had happened to J.G., she did not think Stepfather had done anything
  inappropriate.Â  Stepfather, who had moved out of the home two weeks
  prior to the hearing, attended but did not testify.  
Following
  the review hearing, the family court ordered Stepfather to have no further
  contact with K.G. or J.G. It required DSS to enter Stepfatherâ€™s name into the Central
  Registry of Child Abuse and Neglect based on the courtâ€™s finding that he had
  sexually abused J.G.[2] Â DSS was ordered to retain custody of J.G. and to transfer custody of K.G. to her biological father, allowing Mother
  supervised visitation with K.G.Â  Stepfather
  and Mother appeal the order, contending the court erred in admitting J.G.â€™s out-of-court
  statements of his alleged sexual abuse by Stepfather.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOn appeal from an
  order of the family court, the Court of Appeals has jurisdiction to find facts
  in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Calcutt
    v. Calcutt, 282 S.C. 565, 568, 320 S.E.2d 55, 57 (Ct. App. 1984). Â Even
  under this broad scope of review, the appellant must convince us that the trial
  judge erred. Â Id.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother and
  Stepfather argue the family court erred by allowing the admission of J.G.â€™s out-of-court
  statements to Godfrey and Sands. Â We disagree. Â 
Testimony
  of the out-of-court statements of a child under the age of twelve will be
  admitted in a family court proceeding where abuse or neglect is alleged if the
  court finds the child is unavailable to testify for one of five statutory
  reasons, and the childâ€™s out-of-court statements possess particularized
  guarantees of trustworthiness.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-1-180 (Supp. 2006).Â  The
  first requirement for admission of J.G.â€™s out-of-court statements was clearly
  met.Â  Here, J.G. was eight years old in 2005 when he told Godfrey and Sands of
  his alleged sexual abuse by Stepfather and was age ten at the time they
  testified to his statements. Â 
As
  to the requirement of unavailability, Mother and Stepfather contend the court
  erred by relying on Jonesâ€™s testimony in finding that J.G. was unavailable to
  testify. Â We disagree.Â   
A
  child is unavailable to testify when there is a substantial likelihood he will suffer
  severe emotional trauma from testifying at the proceeding, on videotape, or on
  closed-circuit television. Â S.C. Code Ann Â§ 19-1-180(B)(2)(a)(v). Â Jones, who
  testified regarding the trauma J.G. would suffer if required to testify to the
  alleged abuse, is a licensed social worker and led individual and group therapy
  sessions that included J.G. for over a year.Â  She testified to the progress J.G.
  made during his year in residential treatment and expressed the opinion that
  requiring him to discuss his sexual abuse would cause severe trauma and could
  cause him to regress.Â  Jonesâ€™s opinion is bolstered by Godfreyâ€™s testimony regarding
  J.G.â€™s severe reaction when he disclosed the alleged abuse to Godfrey in
  October 2005. Â Additionally, guardian ad litem, Robert Higgins, agreed that J.G.
  should not be required to testify personally or by videotape.Â  We find the
  evidence presented at the hearing was sufficient to support the family courtâ€™s
  finding that J.G. was unavailable to testify in any manner because there was a
  substantial likelihood that he would suffer severe emotional trauma.  
In
  order to be admissible, South Carolina Code Section 19-1-180(B)(2)(b) requires a
  childâ€™s out-of-court statement to possess particularized guarantees of trustworthiness.
  Â Here, the court went to great lengths to support its finding of these
  guarantees by considering (1) J.G.â€™s personal knowledge of the events he described
  to Sands and Godfrey; (2) J.G.â€™s age and maturity at the time he reported the
  sexual abuse to the witnesses; (3) the credibility of Sandsâ€™s and Godfreyâ€™s
  testimony; (4) the absence of a motive for J.G. to falsify or distort the
  information he reported to Sands and Godfrey; (5) the internal consistency and â€œthe
  ring of veracityâ€ J.G.â€™s statements possessed; and (6) the fact that Stepfather
  had the opportunity to commit the alleged acts of sexual abuse.Â  See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 19-1-180(D)(1)-(10) (listing factors a court may consider in
  determining whether a childâ€™s out-of-court statement contains particularized
  guarantees of trustworthiness). Â The family court found J.G.â€™s out-of-court statements
  to be trustworthy and â€œthis Court will give great deference to the family
  courtâ€™s determination on the issue of trustworthiness.â€ Â Richland Co. Dept.
    of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998). Â We
  find no error in the family courtâ€™s determination that J.G.â€™s out-of-court
  statements possessed particularized guarantees of trustworthiness.  
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the order of the family court is  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Stepfather was already listed in the South Carolina
  Directory of Sex Offenders based on his 1997 conviction for committing a lewd
  act on a child under the age of sixteen.Â
